html:
Etymology[edit]

From Proto-Indo-European *bew- (“swelling”)[1][2], same source as Middle Dutch puyl (“bag”) and Lithuanian bule (“buttocks”). Related to bulla (“sealed document”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈbul.li.oː/, [ˈbʊl̠.l̠i.oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈbul.li.o/, [ˈbul.li.ɔ]

Verb[edit]

bulliō (present infinitive bullīre, perfect active bullīvī or bulliī, supine bullītum); fourth conjugation

  1. I bubble
  2. I boil

Derived terms[edit]

  • *bullicāre
  • bullītiō
  • bullītus
  • combulliō
  • ēbulliō
  • perbulliō
  • rebulliō
  • subbulliō
 

Descendants[edit]

  • Catalan: bullir
  • Corsican: bodda
  • Franco-Provençal: bolyir, bodre
  • Old French: boillir
    • English: boil
    • French: bouillir
  • Friulian: bulî
  • Galicia: bulir
  • Italian: bollire
  • Occitan: bolir
  • Portuguese: bulir, borbulhar (via Vulgar Latin)
  • Romansch: buglir, bugleir
  • Sardinian: bodhire, boddire, bodhiri, buddire, budhire, vudhire
  • Sicilian: vùgghiri
  • Spanish: bullir
  • Venetian: bojir, bugir, bojer, bójar, bogir, bóger, bógiar

References[edit]

  • bullio in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • bullio in Charles du Fresne du Cange’s Glossarium Mediæ et Infimæ Latinitatis (augmented edition, 1883–1887)
  • bullio in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  1. ^ Roberts, Edward A. (2014) A Comprehensive Etymological Dictionary of the Spanish Language with Families of Words based on Indo-European Roots, Xlibris Corporation, →ISBN, p. 202 & 750
  2. ^ Etymonline - boil
